2. Workspace Isolation - Each agent gets its own cloned workspace directory, enabling parallel work on the same
codebase
3. Session Management - tmux sessions with fixed window sizes (120x40), pipe-pane logging, PID tracking
4. Real-time Dashboard - React SPA with:
- Live terminal output via WebSocket
- Git diff viewing across agents
- Session controls (spawn, dispose, attach)
Current State
- Version: v0.5 - "Mostly working, occasionally on fire"
- Recent changes: Git status polling improvements, spawn error handling, first-run wizard fixes
- Modified files: SessionDetailPage.jsx, dashboard handlers/server.go
- New component: NudgeNikModal.jsx (untracked)
Technology Stack
- Backend: Go 1.21+, tmux, git, gorilla/websocket
- Frontend: React 18, Vite, xterm.js, react-diff-viewer
I'm ready to assess what other coding agents working in this workspace might need. What interactions or context would
you like me to review?

- Something else?
I'm in assessment mode - just let me know what context you'd like me to gather before the agent continues.
‚è∫ On macOS, you have several options to display a file's hex values:
Built-in Tools
hexdump (comes with macOS):
hexdump -C filename.txt
- -C shows canonical hex+ASCII display (most readable)
- Bytes in hex on the left, ASCII representation on the right
xxd (usually available):
xxd filename.txt
- Similar to hexdump -C
- Part of vim package, typically preinstalled
od (octal dump):
od -A x -t x1z -v filename.txt
- More complex syntax
- -A x = hex offsets
- -t x1z = one-byte hex with ASCII
Third-party Tool (nicer output)
hexyl (needs install via Homebrew):
brew install hexyl
hexyl filename.txt
- Colorized output
- Shows null bytes, whitespace visually
- More modern UI
Quick Check
Test which you have:
which hexdump xxd od hexyl
hexdump -C or xxd are the most commonly used and should already work on your Mac.
